steady.translation[0].definitions[0].def: continuing or developing gradually or without stopping, and not likely to change
steady.translation[0].definitions[1].def: firmly held in a particular position and not moving or shaking
steady.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: It takes a steady hand to perform surgery.
Keep the camera steady while you take a picture.
steady.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if someone’s voice is steady, or they look at you in a steady way, they seem calm and do not stop speaking or looking at you
steady.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: There were tears in her eyes, but her voice was steady.
He could not meet Connor’s steady gaze.
steady.translation[0].definitions[3].def: someone who is steady is sensible and you can depend on them
steady.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: We're making steady progress in reducing the unemployment rate.
During the 1960s most of the Western world enjoyed steady economic growth.
The campus has benefited from a steady increase in student numbers.
The result has been a steady decline in membership.
All day long a steady stream of customers came and went.
They need a steady supply of educated workers.
He moved at a slow and steady pace through the maze of corridors.
A recent poll showed his approval rating holding steady at 53 percent.
She is making a slow but steady recovery.
steady.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to hold someone or something so they become more balanced or controlled, or to become more balanced or controlled
steady.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The plane steadied, and the passengers relaxed.
He reached the chair and steadied himself.
steady.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to stop increasing or decreasing and remain about the same
steady.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The dollar has steadied after early losses on the money markets.
steady.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to become calmer, or to make someone do this
steady.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Tamar took a deep breath to steady her nerves.
Jess is a steadying influence on the rest of the team.
steady.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a boyfriend or girlfriend that someone has been having a romantic relationship with
steady.translation[4].definitions[0].def: used when you want to tell someone to be careful or not to cause an accident
steady.translation[4].definitions[0].exa: Steady! You nearly knocked me over.
steady.translation[5].definitions[0].def: happening, developing, or moving in a continuous gradual way
steady.translation[5].definitions[0].exa: There has been a steady decline in demand over the past 12 months.
The market has experienced three years of steady growth.
We continue to make steady progress in improving key areas of our business.
steady.translation[5].definitions[1].def: staying at about the same level
steady.translation[5].definitions[1].exa: Software dealers found that prices are steady in spite of the currency fluctuation.
In December, energy prices plunged 1.4% after holding steady the month before.
steady.translation[5].definitions[2].def: a job or work that will definitely continue over a long period of time
steady.translation[5].definitions[2].exa: For years, the promise of steady work attracted waves of immigrants to the area.
steady.translation[6].definitions[0].def: to stop increasing or decreasing and stay about the same, or to make something do this
steady.translation[6].definitions[0].exa: The dollar has steadied after early losses on the money markets.
Some cautious buying by Japanese life insurance companies steadied the market.
